executive_summary: Crop service companies assist in a variety of support services that make them integral to businesses throughout the agriculture sector. Performance is the aggregate result of many different types of services. Despite slow growth in the industry's largest market segment, fruit and vegetable farming, revenue has grown at a CAGR of 7.9% through the end of 2024, reaching an estimated $40.7 billion. Grains like corn and wheat and oilseed crops like soybeans have become more significant in providing for a rising global population. Corn production, which requires services such as crop dusting, has become essential. US renewable energy quotas have pushed for the crop's use in ethanol production, increasing revenue generated from this segment. In 2020, normal operations were disrupted by the outbreak of COVID-19. Some farms

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry Growth Has Continued Despite Disruptions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In 2018, China placed tariffs on several US crops, limiting demand and crop prices. Decreased revenue for crop producers slowed industry growth slightly, but it continued through 2023. Demand from downstream industries was disrupted again in 2020 by the COVID-19 pandemic. Many farms that faced a surplus still needed to use agricultural services to maintain their crops and prevent major production declines in the long term. Crop service providers often help farms deal with volatility and uncertainty, so as the Agriculture sector has faced higher volatility, crop service companies have benefited. So long as farms remain in business, there will always be demand for crop service providers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Farmers Are Outsourcing Work To Crop Service Providers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Crop support services primarily generate revenue through labor-oriented services included under the farm labor contracting and postharvest crop activities segments. Farms have struggled to hire staff to meet production needs because farming activities are highly seasonal, resulting in labor shortages at crucial times. Outsourcing work to crop service providers enables farmers to eliminate the problem by finding trained workers at reasonable prices when they need them. Contracting companies retain these workers year-long and apply them to different farms and crops at different stages of the farming process.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: There is a Shortage of Skilled Workers in the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A large portion of skilled laborers working farm jobs are not US citizens. However, farm labor has become less appealing to non-US nationals in recent years. Several states have implemented strict anti-immigrant policies, making finding and keeping a job harder. The majority of immigrants in farm labor come from Mexico, but immigration has stalled in recent years as the country's manufacturing sector has boomed, providing competitive wages. The industry's labor-intensive services have declined as a share of revenue. Meanwhile, crop service providers have increased average wages to help retain workers.

As organic produce has become increasingly popular, crop service companies have found new opportunities to provide specialty services. New organic growers need specialty inputs, access to uncontaminated equipment and technical assistance from experts familiar with organic growing techniques. Organic production is typically more costly than non-organic crop growing. Organic growing has a higher labor intensity without pesticides and herbicides because farms need staff to employ non-chemical pest prevention techniques.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: An Increase in Planted Acreage is Expected to Sustain Profit
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While there are limits to the supply of available farmland, as crop prices grow, farms will shift their fields to focus on high-value crops. As the number of acres dedicated to high-yield crops increases, farmers will seek more help planting and harvesting. Genetically modified crops and seeds will be used more widely, resulting in higher yields and leading to a greater need for outsourced assistance. Crop prices set by farmers are expected to increase due to farmers consolidating and gaining greater bargaining power. This trend will likely result in farms being resistant to price increases from industry operators.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Providers Will Likely Have Difficulty Maintaining a Workforce
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Wage costs have increased and will likely continue to grow as service providers struggle to retain a knowledgeable and sizeable workforce. The two biggest services, soil preparation and postharvest activities, are labor-intensive. Foreign-born workers, mostly from Mexico, comprise a significant portion of this labor. The Mexican agriculture sector has had strong growth in recent years. Jobs in Mexico have been able to increase wages, forcing US producers to compete. Immigration policy may also cause issues within the industry; current legislation deters many agricultural workers or leads them to work on farms illegally.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Legislation Aimed at Cotton Growing is Expected to Threaten Industry Revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Farm wage costs are expected to decrease modestly, driven by ongoing reductions in farm employment and tight farm labor supplies. This will encourage greater capital investment in new technologies to improve service efficiencies. Automating some of the labor-intensive services will help decrease labor costs. However, revenue will be derived more from capital-intensive services such as cotton ginning rather than from labor-intensive services such as fruit harvesting. Cotton growing has come under attack in recent years for its effects on the environment and for its demands on water resources. These concerns are gaining more attention from policymakers thanks to pressure from lobby groups.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Technology Creates Opportunities for Crop Service Providers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As farming equipment continues to advance, crop service providers will need to innovate and invest to keep up with production trends. As farms look to reduce costs and stay ahead of competitors, farm support services that offer the latest technology will have an advantage. Crop service companies can use artificial intelligence to automate irrigation systems, manage crop rotation, predict crop yields and perform other crop support services. Crop service companies have been able to use drones to monitor crop health and target pesticide and herbicide applications.

industry_definition: Enterprises in this industry provide support activities for growing crops. Some examples of these support activities include cotton ginning, soil treatment, crop harvesting, farm labor contracting and postharvest crop activities.
key_trends: The Crop Services industry is highly fragmented and characterized by the presence of companies modest in revenue and employment. The top four participants in this industry account for less than 5.0% of revenue, combined.

Consolidation has been concentrated in specific segments of the industry where economies of scale can be realized. Businesses engaged in contracted harvesting are unlikely to consolidate activities because there are limited efficiency savings to be achieved from doing so.

The Crop Services industry provides support services to farms such as crop dusting, crop harvesting and labor contracting. Since the industry provides a wide variety of services, falling demand in one segment may be offset by positive results in another.
Farmers and crop service providers have been experiencing a labor shortage. Companies are losing workers because of higher wage costs and strict immigration policies.

market_segmentation.segment_description: A small but significant market segment in this industry is cotton growers who pass on their entire harvest to gins. This is a stable market that has experienced growth due to ongoing demand for cotton products. Because recent floods in Pakistan and India limited world supplies, domestic cotton growers felt increased global demand for their crop.

The second-largest market for the industry is oilseed and grain growers, which require mainly machinery-based services like soil preparation, crop spraying and harvesting. This market consists primarily of growers of corn and general cash grains, as well as wheat and soybeans. Corn and soybean farmers in the United States have been increasingly using genetically modified seeds, which are resistant to pesticides and herbicides, causing demand for these services in particular to grow.

Fruit and vegetable growing industries are the largest buyers of crop support services, making up the majority of revenue. Farmers mainly supply the fresh market where there is an increasing emphasis on quality and presentation, so crews of specially trained workers pick most fruit and vegetables by hand. The produce is processed at a packing shed, which includes cooling, grading and packing. These services are often fully outsourced by farmers who lack the scale and resources to set up their own packing sheds.

Other market segments make up the remaining portion of revenue and include nuts, peanuts and tobacco growers, in addition to sugarcane, sugar beet and hay farmers. Peanut farmers have reduced their demand for services dramatically over the past decade, as deregulation in 2002 has led to a large number of farms closing down. Sugarcane and sugar beet farm numbers have also been declining due to a lack of competitiveness against foreign farmers, leading to diminished demand for support services.

products_and_services.product_description: Cotton gins separate the cotton fiber from its husk. Once ginned, the cotton is sold to spinning mills and later used to produce fabric.

To prepare soil for planting, it must be loosened so that roots can take hold. This segment accounts for the largest share of companies at 44.2%, but each provider employs only about six people on average.
Crop harvesting, primarily done by machine, is implemented when crops are grown under contract with downstream processors or wholesalers.

Postharvest activities are the preparations made for crops to be packaged, marketed, sold or processed further. Examples include almond hulling and shelling; fruit sorting, grading and packing; hulling and shelling of nuts; sun-drying of fruits and vegetables; vegetable sorting, grading and packing; tobacco grading; and sun-drying of fruits and vegetables.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Farm Labor Contractors and Crew Leaders
products_and_services.product_description: Farmers need to employ additional workers during peak periods like harvest, meaning their share of industry employment is fairly small. Contractors are especially important in citrus groves or fruit orchards where almost all fruit harvested for the fresh fruit market is handpicked by trained harvest crews.

Farm managers usually oversee citrus groves, orchards and vineyards on a contract or fee basis on behalf of owners. Operational activities carried out by managers include harvesting, cultivating and other agricultural support activities.

tier_1_suppliers: Farm, Lawn & Garden Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Aircraft, Marine & Railroad Transportation Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Tractors & Agricultural Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Fruit & Vegetable Markets in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The volume of planted acreage for crop production does not fluctuate much year-to-year, but prices do. Prices received for that area's crops partially determine a farmer's revenue and increased revenue enables farmers to pay for crop services. In 2023, the Agricultural Price Index is expected to decrease, posing a potential threat to the industry.

business_locations.location_description: California alone accounts for an estimated 19.3% of all industry establishments. More than one-third of vegetable farming revenue comes from California. The state has a major demand for labor during the harvest period and is responsible for a large proportion of fresh market fruit and vegetables grown in the United States. Fruit and nut farmers are highly concentrated in the state, with more than half the industry's revenue derived from farms in California. Post-harvest activities like fruit and vegetable packing and grading are also located primarily in the West region.

The Cotton Belt runs through this region of the United States and is where most cotton in the country is grown. It passes through the states of Alabama, Arkansas, Louisiana, Georgia, Mississippi and North and South Carolina. Florida is home to an estimated 4.4% of industry service providers and is notably a producer of citrus, among other crops. Contractors are especially important in citrus groves or fruit orchards where almost all fruit harvested for the fresh fruit market is handpicked by trained harvest crews.

A large share of companies working in the soil preparation segment operate in the Plains region, which is the most important area for grain growers due to the climate and topography. In 2020, Iowa produced an estimated 16.2% of the total US corn production, explaining the 5.4% of companies that reside there.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) is chiefly responsible for the enforcement and operation of the Farm Bill, an overarching piece of agricultural legislation that is renewed about every five years, most recently in December 2018. The Farm bill determines the mandatory and discretionary budgets allocated for farm and food assistance.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The United States Grain Standards Act and Agricultural Marketing Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Gave the USDA ability to create the Federal Grain Inspection Service (FGIS), which establishes standards for sampling, process verification, weighing and stowage examination services for evaluating commodities produced by US farms. The FGIS is part of the Grain Inspection, Packers and Stockyards Administration, which enforces official grains standards set in the US.

regulations_points.regulation_title: E N V I R O N M E N T A L  P R O T E C T I O N  A G E N C Y  ( E P A )  R E G U L A T I O N S
regulations_points.regulation_description: Many crop services rely on the use of harsh chemicals, like aerial sprayers, fertilizers and pesticides. The Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) gave the EPA authority to determine which pesticides can be used on farm crops and how, ensuring that pesticide residues in food crops stay within safety standards. Certain EPA programs certify pesticide applicators to ensure that the job can be performed correctly and safely.

regulations_points.regulation_title: F O O D  A N D  D R U G  A D M I N I S T R A T I O N  ( F D A )  R E G U L A T I O N S
regulations_points.regulation_description: The chief responsibility of the FDA is the enforcement of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act. The FDA has three main functions: the provision of scientific expertise, maintenance of food safety and enforcement of food laws. Food safety laws are pertinent to fruit and vegetable sorting, grading and packing, for example, to ensure companies provide safe produce to consumers.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Service providers must learn and follow strict USDA, EPA and FDA regulations. Failure to comply with regulations, laws and other rules governing support services for crop production can subject providers to civil remedies and administrative penalties.

High capital investment requirements and technology costs can be major obstacles. This is particularly true for cotton ginning, soil preparation, machine-based harvesting and processing, but is not as applicable to labor contracting or management services.

The seasonal nature of many activities intensifies competition since establishments have a specific window of time to generate revenue. Farmers prefer long-term agreements with known providers, which makes it difficult for entrants to establish a foothold without name recognition.

basis_points.basis_description: The Crop Services industry is highly fragmented and characterized by the presence of companies modest in revenue and employment. The top four participants in this industry account for less than 5.0% of revenue, combined.

Consolidation has been concentrated in specific segments of the industry where economies of scale can be realized. Businesses engaged in contracted harvesting are unlikely to consolidate activities because there are limited efficiency savings to be achieved from doing so.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is characterized by many companies, small in employment and revenue. Companies are highly fragmented and market share concentration is extremely low.
The top four companies in this industry account for less than 5.0% of revenue, combined. Nonemployer companies make up about 90.0% of industry enterprises.
More than four-fifths of employer companies in this industry have fewer than 20 employees.
Minimal consolidation activity keeps the level of concentration low. Consolidation has been concentrated in specific segments of the industry where economies of scale can be realized.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs are Increasing as the Price of Fertilizer Goes Up
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases associated with providing services to farmers include seed, fertilizer and chemicals. These costs depend on the size of the service provider, declining for larger companies since they benefit from economies of scale and have the ability to negotiate lower prices from suppliers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation Costs Depend on the Level of Capital Investment
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation and maintenance costs are high for service providers engaged in capital-intensive processes, such as ginning, aerial spraying and broad acre crop harvesting. Costs are especially high for companies providing aerial spraying services, as the number of takeoffs and landings speed up wear and tear. Depreciation can fluctuate year to year depending on demand from agricultural segments that rely on capital-intensive services, like cotton ginning.

Labor shortages have persisted over the past few years and fruit growers have been affected by a lack of trained crews. This has delayed harvests and hurt the reputation of service providers, which is extremely valuable in a referral-based business.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for crop services is tied to the success of crop producers, which is determined by acreage, crop yields, the value of production and interference from crop pests and diseases. The COVID-19 pandemic affected the agriculture sector by decreasing demand for crops from restaurants and leaving farmers with huge surpluses.

volatility_points.volatility_title: There is a variety of sources of revenue for crop service providers
volatility_points.volatility_description: If there is a drop in the revenue from one segment, this can easily be offset by an increase in another. If there is a large harvest of produce requiring handpicking, companies that handle machine picking of other fruits and vegetables could suffer. Most services are needed in the production of an array of crops, so providers are resistant to seasonality in their jobs. Cotton ginning is an exception to this rule. Ginners depend entirely on the yield volume of one specific crop.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: THE AUTOMATION OF LABOR LEADS TO HIGHER YIELDS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Various robots are being developed to pick fruit and vegetables, dramatically reducing the amount of labor required at harvest time. US-based Harvest Croo Robotics has created a strawberry-picking robot capable of harvesting the same quantity that a team of 30 workers could achieve in a day. Not only does automation reduce labor times and lead to higher yields, it allows companies to save on labor costs.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: SMART TECHNOLOGY CAN BE USED TO ENSURE QUALITY AND REDUCE WASTE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Farmers are using sensors, robots and drones in order to find problems that could impact the harvest and resolve them before damage is done. These technologies can be used to guarantee the quality of their products, as they can tell precisely when produce is ready to be harvested.

FAQs.question: What agencies are your primary regulators? Have you had any compliance issues in the past?
FAQs.answer: Industry companies are regulated by the USDA, but not to the same extent as other crop growers.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Trade associations are necessary due to the low level of concentration.

FAQs.question: How does volatility impact your company's profitability?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins are largely determined by crop prices and fertilizer and other input costs.

FAQs.question: How does your farm compensate for the seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Crop service companies are able to maintain steady profit by providing services to multiple types of farms.

FAQs.question: What steps can you take to increase the quality of your after-sales service?
FAQs.answer: Effective procedures need to be established for responding to inquiries made by farmers. Ongoing support helps companies establish loyal customers. For instance, crop dusters may offer to inspect crops to ensure that spraying has been successful.

FAQs.question: Have you recently changed your services to accommodate new regulations?
FAQs.answer: Some providers use chemicals during their service, which is under strict regulation. Compliance with the Environmental Protection Agency is especially important for companies providing aerial spraying services.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Have you had any problems with reliability in the past?
FAQs.answer: A good reputation is important for any company engaged in providing services because they often rely on referrals for new business.

FAQs.question: How is the agricultural price index reflective of the crop industry at large? How do you prepare for volatility in prices received for crops?
FAQs.answer: Prices received for that area's crops can swing wildly based on a variety of factors, including weather conditions, global agricultural production and demand from domestic and foreign food manufacturers. So growth in the agricultural price index increases demand for industry services.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of the prime rate? Are you prepared for an increase in demand due to rising interest rates?
FAQs.answer: Heavy loan-servicing costs increase demand for contracted services in harvesting and other capital-intensive farming activities. Therefore, rising interest rates, represented by the prime rate as a proxy, will encourage crop farmers to use more of the industry's support services.

FAQs.question: How do you make up for lost revenue when crop production revenue is low? Do you have fixed contracts with downstream farms?
FAQs.answer: Any increase in revenue for crop production will result in an increase in demand for various support services.
